The grand principle maintained by these reformers\97the 
249
same that had been held by the Waldenses, by Wycliffe, by John Huss, by Luther, Zwingle, and those who united with them\97was the infallible authority of the Holy Scriptures as a rule of faith and practice. They denied the right of popes, councils, Fathers, and kings, to control the conscience in matters of religion. The Bible was their authority, and by its teaching they tested all doctrines and all claims.
